metadata.title: OSCAL Security Assessment Results for IoTGoat Firmware (Raspberry Pi 2)

results.title: IoTGoat Firmware: Binary Security Assessment Results
results.description: Comprehensive security assessment performed on IoTGoat-raspberry-pi2-sysupgrade.img (raw ARMv7 firmware, 33306530 bytes, with entry point at 0x7C00/31744). 10 filtered, post-false-positive findings are documented here, mapped to appropriate NIST 800-53 controls. Evidence sources include YARA scans, extracted embedded strings, and binary structure analysis.

findings.title: Potential Hardcoded Credentials Detected
findings.description: Critical: YARA rule 'Hardcoded_Credentials' matched 4 instances with binary evidence, indicating likely hardcoded usernames, passwords or secrets in the firmware (CWE-798). Confidence: 0.85 (HIGH). This represents a severe risk for unauthorized access, especially in IoT contexts. Evidence: Embedded strings and YARA matches.

findings.title: Weak Cryptographic Algorithms Detected
findings.description: Medium: Deprecated or weak cryptographic algorithms detected via 'Crypto_Weak_Algorithms' YARA rule: 55 matches, indicating insecure cryptography in firmware (CWE-327). Confidence: 0.80 (HIGH). Weak cryptography exposes data and communication to compromise.

findings.title: Use of Dangerous Buffer Handling Functions
findings.description: High: Buffer overflow-prone standard library functions (e.g., strcpy, strcat, gets) identified via YARA (9 matches), directly increasing memory corruption/code execution risks (CWE-120). Confidence: 0.90 (HIGH). Validated via strings and patterns in ARMv7 binary section.

findings.title: Potential Command Injection Vectors
findings.description: High: Direct invocation of system command interfaces from user-controlled sources identified (YARA: 96 matches, functions akin to system/exec; CWE-78). Confidence: 0.80 (HIGH). These present a substantive command injection risk in networked firmware.

findings.title: Potential Command Injection Vectors
findings.description: High: Same as above, mapped to Access Enforcement due to privilege escalation risk. Confidence: 0.80 (HIGH).

findings.title: Firmware Encryption Key Exposure
findings.description: Critical: Exposure of firmware encryption keys/material observed (YARA: 7 matches; CWE-321). Confidence: 0.90 (HIGH). Keys found directly in the static binary. Severe compromise of encrypted content and device trust.

findings.title: Significant Code Obfuscation Detected
findings.description: Medium: Substantial presence of code obfuscation detected (YARA: 49,784 matches; CWE-327). Confidence: 0.70 (MEDIUM). May indicate deliberate attempt to hinder review or possible malicious concealment.

findings.title: Data Exfiltration Capabilities
findings.description: High: YARA detection (222 matches) of patterns associated with data exfiltration (CWE-200). Confidence: 0.70 (MEDIUM). Binary evidence suggests the presence of network beacons or suspicious data movement.

findings.title: ROP Gadgets Detected â€” Return-Oriented Programming
findings.description: High: Multiple ROP (Return-Oriented Programming) gadgets (YARA: 4,985 matches; CWE-119) detected with 0.80 (HIGH) confidence. Indicates the firmware is susceptible to ROP chaining, especially in the presence of other memory corruption vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Anti-Debug and Anti-Tamper Techniques Present
findings.description: High: Anti-debugging and anti-tamper routines present (YARA: 15 matches; CWE-327). Confidence: 0.80 (HIGH). While sometimes defensive, may complicate incident response and analysis.

findings.title: Development Artifacts Present
findings.description: Low: Debug symbols and development artifact patterns located (YARA: 770 matches; CWE-215). Confidence: 0.70 (MEDIUM). May disclose internal implementation or facilitate reverse engineering.
